dialogueHeader.title: THE FRENCH TONGVE
dialogueHeader.author: WODROEPHE JOHN
dialogueHeader.contemporaneity: Source text dates from same year as the first printing / original speech event

textBibliography.frontMatter: THE MARROW OF THE FRENCH TONGVE. CONTAINING 1. RULES FOR THE TRUE PRONUNCIATION OF EUERY LETTER AS IT IS WRITTEN OR SPOKEN. 2. AN EXACT GRAMMAR, CONTAINING THE NINE PARTS OF SPEECH OF THE FRENCH TONGUE. 3. DIALOGUES IN FRENCH AND ENGLISH, FITTED TO ALL KIND OF DISCOURSE FOR COURTIERS, CITIZENS, OR COUNTRY-MEN, IN THEIR AFFAIRES AT HOME, OR TRAUELLING ABROAD. (...) SO EXACTLY COLLECTED AND COMPILED BY THE GREAT PAINES AND INDUSTRY OF M. IOHN WODROEPHE, THAT THE MEANEST CAPACITY EITHER FRENCH OR ENGLISHMAN, THAT CAN BUT READE, MAY IN A SHORT TIME BY HIS OWNE INDUSTRY WITHOUT THE HELPE OF ANY TEACHER ATTAINE TO THE PERFECTION OF BOTH LANGUAGES. (...) THE SECOND EDITION: REVIEWED AND PURGED OF MUCH GROSSE ENGLISH, AND DIVERS ERRORS COMMITTED IN THE FORMER EDITION PRINTED AT DORT. LONDON, PRINTED FOR RICHARD MEIGHEN, AT THE SIGNE OF THE LEG IN THE STRAND, AND IN SAINT DUNSTANS CHURCHYARD IN FLEETSTREET. 1625. PP. 173.1 - 194.33 SAMPLE 1 PP. 233.1 - 235.32 SAMPLE 2

dialogueText.comment: FIRST COLUMN ON EACH PAGE OF THE SOURCE TEXT, IN FRENCH, IS OMITTED BELOW. FOR CLARITY, SPEAKER NAMES MISSING FROM THE SECOND COLUMN, I.E. THE ENGLISH TEXT, ARE SUPPLIED FROM THE FRENCH VERSION IN THE FIRST COLUMN.
EMPTY LINES IN THE SECOND COLUMN WHICH REFLECT THE LONGER TEXT IN THE FIRST COLUMN ARE OMITTED.
LITERAL TRANSLATIONS FROM FRENCH EXPLAINED IN NOTES IN THE MARGIN OF THE SOURCE TEXT ARE OMITTED BELOW.

sample.head: A DISCOURSE BETWEENE THE BURGUER AND THE YEAMAN
sample.dialogue: Ho Yeaman, from whence lead you that load of wood? that load of fagots, of great wood, and of logges?

Sir, I bring it from the wood: I bring it from the forrest: I bring it from the field, from the groue, from the hedges, from the vnderwood, from the bramble bushes: from our land towne, from our village, and from our hammell.
Is it good? is it dry? is it wood of birch? is it oaken wood?
O yea Sir, it burneth well: it burneth like brimstone.

Yeamanesse, good wife, haue you no fresh egges? haue you any ducke egges? some pullets? some fresh butter? some sweet or sowre milke? some good sweet creame? some creamed, or curdded milke? any churned milke, or new cheese?
Yes, yes, Sir: O yea! I haue some of all sorts, and good to eate.
How much sell you the dozen of fresh egges? the pound of butter? the pint, or the pot of your milke?
Sir, come your wayes and see, and I will giue you good cheape of all.
I will, well, let me see it then if it please you.
Goe to, come, come: of which doth it please you to haue Sir?

I will some of all sorts, measure me, sell me: make me good measure: measure mee well: sell me good cheape: ouerprize not the price thereof: Goe to, take your money: render me my rest: but how much will you haue? how much should I giue you? tell me quickly.
Sir, you know it well: you know it so well as I: hold, take women then. Adieu till I see you againe good wife.

Ho, speake good wife: hola, speake: hearke here a little: haue you spunne the fine flaxe, and the hempe of my Lady, &c. or mine? haue not you bleached my fine linnen for to make some shirts? my threed, and my coorse linnen for to make some sackes; and some other paultry for mine houshold, and for to accommodate my children and my seruants?
No truly Sir yet: for I haue had no leasure since: it hath alwayes beene drie weather since, I assure you.
Is not yet my corne ripe in the fields?

Yes Sir, it is long agone: it behoues you but make ready your worke folkes: but your mowers, your shearers, and your cutters of corne.
REPETITION OF PREVIOUS UTTERANCE OMITTED HERE.
Haue you fed my horses, and my stoned horses? my mares, breeding mares, and colts: my cowes, and my calues? my bulls, and my beeues? my rammes, sheepe, lambs, and my ewes? &c.
Yes Sir, and Madame; all are well.
My bore, and my hogges, my sowes and my pigges, do they feed well with oakornes of oake? with chesnuts, or other graine?
Ho, ho, Sir, a Sow or a Hog doth eate of euery thing, though it should bee of a stone, or of iron.
Are they in the wood, in the groue, in the forrest, or in the stie?
Yea, yea, Sir: O yes! they are alwayes in the wood.
Are there any of them eaten with the wolfe, with the she-wolfe, with the foxe, with the she-foxe, with the beare, with the she-beare, or with the badger?
O no! for they can defend themselues well with their clawes, with their pawes, and with their great pointed and sharpe teeth.
What say you? is it possible? truly I beleeue it not.
Yea truly it is true: I assure you that it is very true.
Is not this here, my caroch, my coach, my chariot, my cart, and my litter.
Yes, yes, sir, and all their equipage; as the harnesse, the furniture, and their necessities.
Haue you spanged my horses to the chariot?
Yes, Sir, I spanged them the other day for to carrie some dung, and some dunghill, for to fatten the land, the yarde, and the field.

Well, well, it was well done. Till me the land well, the fields, and the yards with the plough, and the harrow: and harrow me also the land, the field, and the yard, after that you shall haue ared, sowne, and accommodated them.
Sir, I shall not faile to doe it: I shall not misse to doe it.

Thresh me well the corne with the flaile in the barne, on the floore: and fan, riddle, and make very cleane, my graine, out of his chaffe, and straw: and chiefly my wheate. Moreouer, feed well, and take heed to my Pigeons, Hennes, and Pullets; to my Peacocke, & to my Peahen: to my Turky cocks, and to my Turkyhens: and to all their little chickens: and aboue all to my Doue-coat.
Sir, there shall be no fault in all that: wee shall take heed to all.
Adieu good man, and good wife: God keepe you from euill.
Adieu Sir, adieu Madam vntill the next market day.
sample.head: A DISCOURSE BETWEENE A CAP. AND HIS INFERIOUR OFFICERS AND SOULDJERS.
sample.dialogue: My Lieutenant, mine Ensigne, my Serjeans, and my Corporals.
What doth it please you sir? will you haue any thing?
I beleeue we must march, take our way, and make a voyage to morrow: that it behoues vs to beate to the fields one of these dayes, or very soone.
Sir where if it please you? in what part must we goe? march? take our iourney? or make our voyage?
Doe not you know? against the enemy, in the fields, in the champion field.
Sir, what sort of enemy? what sort of folkes be they?
The Spaniard, the Castilian, the Italian and the Albanians.
The ill man breake his armes, the head and the legges.
Amen, amen: so be it: so may it happen vnto him.
Sir, is he so neere? is hee so nigh? is hee verie neare?
Yes, yes: see here he is at hand: behold, he is here at our flankes: see here hee is behind vs: see here he is within a shot of a cannon, of a musket, of a harquebuse, of a pistol, to vs.
Then shall it be for his harme, for his damage, and to his losse.

Sir, since it is so, cause the horsemen to aduance, the troops, the men at armes, the carbins, the dragons, the light horsemen, the fantassins, the lanciers, the scoppetiers, the harquebusiers on horsebacke: and all the other braue Voluntaries that follow after vs.

Sir, see here they are all: see here they come: and are all armed, equipaged and ready. Behold also the barded horses that conuoy the cannon, the baggage, and all the munition, to wit, the powder, the bullets, the cannon bullets, the match, the cariage, the harnesse, the attirals, the victuallers, the pinoniers, the mules, the mulers, the asses, the nags; and all their equipage: and all others munition and furniture of war.

Musketiers, be ready: Pikemen aduance you to the front, quickly, quickly. Halt: hold you still without any words: silence.
Giue the word to the Sergeant from hand to hand. Make them keepe their rankes, and hold them ready for all occasions.
Sir, we will doe it, and protest all to die and liue with you.

I thanke you my masters: I thanke you fellowes. Have courage my masters: take courage fellowes: if it please God we shall all be rich: we shall all be mounted, equipaged, and in better order to morrow: wee shall well recompence our long journeyes, and our great trauell. For the Spaniards haue gold chaines about their neckes, and great store of pistols in their purses; without other fine white money, so well rials, as mattes: and many other sorts of money very fine and good. Sa, sa, prepare you: for they come and tell vs, That the enemie is here at hand. Do not ye heare his horses neigh? Light your matches from hand to hand. Light your matches at both the ends. Cocke your matches: bullet in mouth. A brace of Sergeants from hand to hand. Keepe your rankes: to your long order: silence: no words, momme, halt, halt. Musketiers, are ye ready? giue fire, giue fire. Ho, ho, let vs charge, charge, kill, kill. Shoot, harquebusiers and musketiers. Haw pikemen, aduance, aduance: charge, charge, sa, sa, sa. Let vs giue on, let vs lay vpon those robbers, for they shall pay very deare their boldnesse: they shall pay deare their rashnesse and comming. Cut, cut their throats: for euen so well shall they cut yours, if they abide masters of the battell, of the Champion field, of the field, and of our Campe.
sample.head: LITTLE WORDS BETWEENE A SCHOOLE-MASTER, AND ONE OF HIS SCHOLLERS.
sample.dialogue: Master, is the French tongue vneasie, or difficult for to learne.
No, no: in no wise: O no!
Tell mee the reason thereof: tell mee the cause thereof: tell me the subject: tell mee wherefore.
Because (as it seemeth to me) that by the meanes of the grace, the fauour, and the assistance of God, there is nothing done, or ordained by him, but it is easily learned: I say concerning tongues.
Notwithstanding men say, That the Bible, the holy Scriptures, the holy Writs, the holy Letters are very mysticall, and vneasie to be vnderstood?

Well yea of the euill liuers, and of those which neglect the duty which they owe to our Lord: but concerning the faithfull,
they bee but tales, that they vnderstand them not: yea euen so well as they wish, prouided they vse good diligence, therein praying the Lord to reveale to them the true sense thereof.
But who forbids then that euery one should reade it?
The Romish Church, the Church of Rome: the Popish Church: the Church of humane traditions: the Church of men.
Hath it beene forbidden of God? of Iesus Christ?

No neuer: but (contrariwise) it hath been instituted for mens saluation (fearing God) generally to all sorts of men, yong, or old, so well men as women: so well boyes as wenches: so well fathers as mothers: so well children as seruants, and seruing maids: so well men of Church, as men of the fields or trades men.
Why haue those men done that? tell me the reason thereof?
Ile tell it you? Couetousnesse is an euill canker, which hath beene the cause of it, and is yet cause of many other euils in the world.
Then that hath also beene cause that the Lord hath excluded his Word from such folkes?
Yea: and hath blinded them in their wickednesse yet more: because they haue shut the gate on him, when hee hath knocked, desiring (by great mercy) their well and saluation.
But Master, why bring you mee here the passages of the holy Scripture, and sacred things, when I demand you other vocables of little consequence?

It is for feare least all my Schollers should neglect their owne duty towards their Parents, and betters: to wit towards God first, and his holy Word: and also to their Fathers and mothers: Secondly, to their Superiours, and folkes which they ought to reuerence: thirdly, to keepe irrefragable amitie with their brothers and neighbours.
Sir, I see then by that meanes, that carelesnesse, and our lusts, are bad things: are euill vices, obstacles, and lets, which hinder vs to feare the Lord?
Yes truely: truely yea: truely your reason is good.

Sir, doe not you tell mee also that those cursed vices, those cursed lusts: our wicked flesh: the fragile, fraile, and soft worldly things: all sorts of cupidities doe hinder vs to know the Word of God: the heroicall renowne of vertue the chast, and manly
force (which we ought to enjoy betwixt the yong age, vntill the age of Adolescence and virilitie.

Yea, I tell you the pure truth thereof: for euery man that loseth the time after his lusts, doth lose his courage: loseth his renowne: loseth the force of his body: puts his bodie in many dangers: strayeth himselfe from the favours of God: tormenteth his conscience: encurreth many excesses and scabs, excrements, cathaires and euill humours. Moreouer, dulleth his noble memory: putting himselfe also in danger of the pockes, of gangraynes, and vlcers which doe gnaw his body: cuts him the thread of life before euer he come to halfe age: where contrariwise, he who feareth God (taking the time by the end) and reading his Word: and betakes him selfe to study, and to vertue (which bee the true rudder of the faithfull, and generous) shall sit among the learned, and graue men, to giue counsell for the good and state of a Common-wealth. Furthermore, the Lord will fulfill him his Saying, dictated by the holy Ghost, and by the mouth of his seruant, and Prophet Dauid, Saying, &c. VERSE OMITTED.
Maister, doe not the debauches, and our lusts hinder the bringing vp of the youth SOURCE TEXT: yonth , our studies, and foraine tongues? as the Latine, the French, the Italian, and many other.

Truely child, there is no doubt of it: for what more honour can men get in the world then to know to speake foraine tongues? since that by S=t= Pauls own mouth esteemes them worthy to be learned, calling them the grace, and the gift of the Lord.
Maister, is the French tongue very needfull, and profitable among the Nobilitie?

Yea, and yet more profitable among the Merchants: for except it be the Latine: me thinkes, it is the most profitable of all Christendome: and almost, it is so much in vse (if I durst say it) as the Latine, and rather more.
Is it so easie, and docile to bee learned as the Latine?
Yes, much more: yea more then the halfe. LIST OF TITLES AND TERMS OF ADDRESS OMITTED.
sample.head: THE GREAT ORCHARD OF RECREATION: COMPOSED & GATHERED OUT OF SUNDRY DUTCH AUTHORS, AND AFTERWARD TRANSLATED, AND DIUIDED INTO TWELUE CHAPTERS, BOTH IN FRENCH, AND ENGLISH .
THE RISING IN THE MORNING, THE CLOATHING, AND GOODS OF THE CHAMBER; AND SOME OTHER BUSINESSE PARTAINING TO THE SAME. BETWEENE NALANO, TORQUATO: AND RUPSA SERVANT. THE FIRST CHAPTER.
sample.dialogue: Ho! Master Torquato, will you sleepe all the day long?
Who is there? who cals me? who demands me?
One of your Friends: a friend: it is I, are you vp?
Who are you? what demand you? what seeke you?
Good morrow Master Torquato: doe you sleepe yet?
Ah Master Nalano, excuse me, I will rise presently.
Rise at your ease, I will stay for you.
I will come presently and open you the gate.
Not so in haste: be not so hasty: doe not hast you so much.
Behold the gate is open, doth it please you to enter?
God giue you a good morrow.
And to you in like manner Sir: you are most heartily welcome.
I kisse your hands very humbly: were not you yet risen?
No truly Sir, it is not yet so late.
Are not you ashamed to be so long in bed?
I did not sleepe: I did but slumber.
It seemeth to mee that you are yet sleeping?
For to say the truth, I am not yet well awaked.
Ah if sluggishnes were vertue; how many vertuous should there be in the world?
It should be pity: for I should bee of that number.
Now haue you made goods: can you also make the man?
I make the man, and leaue the goods to be made by others.
But how haue you reposed this night?
Well: but I haue had many dreedfull dreames.
Friend of the Muses, you should haue risen at the breake of day.
So am I accustomed to do: but I went late to bed yesternight.
But what do you? why do not you rise?
Ho Rupsa, come hither: Where art thou? what doest thou?
Behold I am here: what doth it please you! what demand you Sir?
Open me that window there, and giue me my cloathes.
Sir, what cloathes doth it please you to put on to day?
Giue me first a cleane shirt, and one of the finest.
Sir, there is but two of them cleane.
Where be all the other? where be all my cleane shirts?
Sir the Landresse hath six of them.
How many haue I in all?
Sir, you haue some three dozen.
Then I want foure.
Excuse me Sir, behold here yet some foule.
Cause them all to bee washed for to morrow.
Ile send them: Ile cause cary them to the Landresse to morrow.
Dispatch thee: giue me a cleane shirt.
Sir, what ruffe-bands will you weare to day?
Those of battiste linnen, or of Cambricke.
Sir, will not you weare falling bands?
No: giue me a ruffeband, it is more warme about my necke.
Sir, here is a ruffe for you.
Loggerhead, seest not thou that it is all wet?
Sir, forgiue it me, for I tooke no heed to it.
Goe and warme it in the Kitchene.
Sir, there is no fire there.
Make only a blaze with a little sticke of wood.
Sir, here it is, put it on the while it is warme.
Take heed there be small strings on it.
Sir, there are on both sides.
Giue me my Wastcoat quickly.
Sir, which will you haue? the wollen one?
No: giue me the knit one.
Sir, what cloathing doth it please you to weare to day?
Those of white satin laid with gold lace.
Sir, they lacke, I know not how many buttons.
Put them on presently.
Sir, I haue neither needle, threed nor thimble.
Goe to the Taylor and borrow one.
Sir; Ile repaire them for to morrow.
Master Nalano, doe not thinke long.
No, no, sir: in the meane time Ile reade in this booke.
Boy, giue me rather my sute of taffata, for it is warme weather.
Sir, it is in the bottome of the Trunke.
You euill boy, why dost not thou take it out?
Sir, I did not thinke you should haue worne it any more, because it is too narrow for you, and is all worne.
Giue me then which thou wilt.
Sir, here is your sute of cut fustian.
Where be the Brushes, that I cannot see them?
Sir, see them there tied to that naile.
Where is the count of all mine apparell?
Sir, they are all in your Trunckes and Coffers.
Bring it me quickly: reade it to me, quickly.
Sir, See there SOURCE TEXT: rhere is first a long night Gown, lyned, and furred with Martinskins. LIST OF CLOTHES OMITTED.
Where is the rest? Is there no other thing?
Sir, the rest is here vp and down the Chamber.
Make shift to finde out the rest, otherwise keepe you well from my hands.
See here be yet two paire of Bootes, the one of Spanish leather, and the other of Neats leather. A paire of Spurs. Three paire of Boothoses. A paire of Pantofles. Your Pumpes. Your night slippers.
Where is all my Linnen, great and small?
Sir, all is in that great Box there.
Go you (Senselesse) look if all be there.'
Sir, I cannot find the key.
Carelesse body that thou art, where hast thou layed it?
I put it this morning in my Pocket: Ha Sir, I haue found it.
Art thou SOURCE TEXT: rhou so poore of memorie?
Sir, I remember not so far as between my mouth and my nose.
Thou shalt neuer make a lodging of three house height.
Sir, can I make a good one, of one onely?
I beleeue, three Trees shall suffice thee to make them.
Sir, neuerthelesse great men come (very often) to dwell in such little lodgings, and low houses.
By the Body that I will not sweare, if I lay my hand on a codgell, Ile make thee stay in thy right senses.
Sir, I can serue you no other wayes.
Thou wilt that I take a log of wood, and swinge thee with it ouer thy backe, or about thine eares.
Sir, God keepe you from doing so: I would not you did that, for much.
I see well now, that he who is bad of Nature, is bad vnto the graue, if God hath not called him.

Sir, see here be a dozen of shirts. 2 doze~ of hand kerchers. As many SOURCE TEXT: may of fallingbands. Eight ruffe bands with their Cuffs wrought with silke. Foure Napkins. Six drinning cloathes. Eight quoifes. 3 paire of sheets. And yet in that combe case, be your combes of Box, and of Iuorie. Your litle Sizars, with your eare-pikers, Pick toothes, small forks: and other things pertaining to the same.
I see now that thou art an honest man: thou hast found it.
Sir, see here bee yet two dozen of points.
Set this Coffer, and this truncke from thence, for they be too hote.
Sir, will you weare shooes to day, or bootes.
No, giue me the shooing horne to pull on my shooes.
Sir, doth it please you that I pull them on to you?
No, thinkest thou that I am so lazie?
What know I? it should neither bee meruell nor miracle.
Trusse vp my points loosly, and not with hard bound knots, for to make me cut them.
Sir here is one that is not tagged. What Girdle doth it please you to weare to day?
Reech me that embrodered with gold, and my sword Hangers of the same.
Sir, doth it please you to weare your Rapier and Poniard to day?
Yes, yes, giue me my Rapier and Poinard.
Sir take this sword, for it is lightest,
Giue me my Sword made of the Ferrara, and Italian Fashion.
Indeed, sir, it hath a faire hilt, and very light.
Reech mee the Combe, for to combe my haire.
Sir, looke there is your come case vpon the Window.
Where be my gloues? I see them not.
Sir, you forgot them yesterday in some part.
Go to the Glouer, and by me a paire of kidleather.
Sir, will you haue them perfumed?
I care not, prouided they keepe my hands fresh and delicate.
My God! you are long a dressing you.
Sir, who goes softly, goes surely and safely: I come presently.
But Sir, what doe you with so many garments?
I cloath the~ according to the weather.
How many haue you to change?
Sir, I haue for to change one euery day in the weeke.
You do not go cloathed as I do? to wit like a figure, and alwayes of one fashion.
Truly sir, you do it for your pleasure, and not of necessitie.
How many sorts haue you of them?
Sir, I haue but of Veluet, of Satin, of Damaske, of Grogeram and of Fustian.
Sir, you are very happy to enjoy of all your commodities so ready.
Yea it is you sir, who enjoyes the pleasures of the world!
No sir, it is you who can pisse in the bed, and say you haue sweat in it.
Sir, I haue nothing but it is at your commandement and seruice.
Sir, I doe acknowledge it, and thanke you very humbly for it.
Sir, I do not as many doe, who thinke neuer to be cloathed, if they haue not their warderobes and trunkes full.
Truly (may bee) Sir, those men haue their cloathing furred with great debts.
Sir, behold therefore, I content my selfe with these few that I haue.
Who is content of a little, enjoyeth SOURCE TEXT: enjoyerh al things.
A content heart, is a good cloake for his shoulders.
Sir, Why do you cloath you so warmlie.
For to liue as it shall please God, and to follow the Prouerbe.
How do you say that Prouerbe?
Cloathe thy selfe warmly: eate oft and little: drinke now and then (if God please) and thou shalt liue long.
Truly Sir, hee who can doe his owne affaires, will doe another mans worse.
He who doth his owne affaires, defileth not much his hands with them.
Sir, if it please you, let vs dispatch, and hast vs a little.
The greatest haste is the least worke, and by spurring to much SOURCE TEXT: muchs make the flight the longer. Ile be more handsome to pare my nailes.
Sir, you anger mee to make mee languish so long.
Sir, I haue not yet washed my face, nor my hands: nor I haue not trussed me.
Sir, are you euery day so long in bed?
Yes sir, sometimes, according as I goe to bed.
You annoy me very much to make me stay for you, and wishing so long for your most agreeable company!
Sir, but what be the mortell paines?

To stay for those that come not: to be in bed and sleepe not: to serue and please not: to haue a horse that goes not: to stray when one desires not: to be at a gate when they open not: and to haue a friend that betrayes thee: are six things for to kill thee. Truly Sir, those bee the paines which I endure, and haue endured very often.
SOURCE TEXT: E. In good truth Sir, I endure the first of them at this present houre.
Sir, beleeue me, you shall endure it no more, for I haue done.
God be praised, haue you once done?
Sir, doth it please you to take a cup of wine before you goe forth?
Sir, it should be no great sinne.
Are you accustomed to drinke in the morning, or to make collation?
I accommodate my selfe with all things, and I am like a Millers sacke, and not as some doe whiles, making consciencce to spit in the Church before folkes, & would doe worse if none should see them.
Ho Rupsa, bring vs hither some drinke.
What is your pleasure Sir, doth it please you to haue any thing?
Bring some bread, some wine, and a napkin.
Sir, I will bring them you presently.
Rinse and wash the glasses and the Cups.
Well Sir, see there they bee faire and cleane.
Poure in some wine, and giue vs some drinke.
Sir, I know not how you can drinke so earely?
Very well Sir. This to your good health.
Sir, I loue it from you, and Ile pledge you with a very good heart.
Rupsa, giue some drinke to Maister Nalano.
Sir, support me in that, for I drinke not often out of meale time.
Sir, the morning drinke is good for to charme the mist.
Sir, doth it please you to haue any other thing?
Giue me my sword, my poniard, and my cloake: helpe me to gird them on me.
Sir, that cloake doth become you very well.
Sir, shall I goe with you?
No, not, dresse vp the Chamber, and shut vp all.
Sir, I pray you let vs loose no more time.
Sir, I am ready, goe before and I will follow you.
I had rather shew my selfe indiscreet, then disobedient.
Hola, Boy. follow me.
Sir, I come, but I go first to shut the gate and the doores.
Thou saiest well: but shut them with the keye.
who shuts well, opens well.
True, and who feareth God, falleth neuer in mischance.
sample.head: A DISCOURSE OF FAMILIAR SPEECH (VPON THE WAY IN THE MORNING): WITH AN OTHER PRETY DISCOURSE OF THE TENIS, BETWEEN THREE FRIENDS: TO WIT, HENRY , IOHN , AND PECENIO THEIR SERUANT. THE SECOND CHAPTER.

dialogue.comment: ONE OF THE THREE FRIENDS IS MISSING FROM THIS HEADING. THE FRENCH LANGUAGE HEADING HAS THOMAS, HENRY AND IEAN.

sample.dialogue: God giue you a good morrow, sir.
And to you likewise sir, a good morrow and good yeare.
The Lord grant you a good morrow Sir.
Sir, the same be giuen vnto you with all happinesse.
Sir, God giue you all good lucke and all prosperity.
Sir, I wish you the same with a good heart.
What are you going to doe so alone?
Sir, I would not be alone in Paradice.
Notwithstanding it is better to be alone then in euill company.
He who betakes himself to be with you is well accompanied.
Sir, how doe you doe this morning?
Sir, ready to doe you any seruice.
Sir how goes it with your health this morning?
Sir, very well, at your commandement.
How haue you done since the other day?
Sir, I haue done well, and found my selfe well, praised be God.
Truly sir, I reioyce alwaies of your welfare.
But whether are you bound to goe in such hast?
Sir, I take my way towards S. Paul his Church SOURCE TEXT: Chutch .
And you sir, whither goe you so alone?
I will goe walke a little.
And you sir, so well as I, whither is it that you doe goe?
Sir, I am going to the Exchange.
Sir, doth it please you to haue company?
Sir, very willingly, if I do not importune you.
No truly sir, I shall be very glad of your company.
And I sir, most glad of yours.
Sir, doth it please you that I keepe you company?
Sir, you shall doe me great honour and pleasure.
Sir, I would not trouble you so much.
No forsooth, sir, you should rather doe me honour.
Sir, doth it please you to goe by land, or by water?
Sir, it is euen as it shall please you, it is all one to me.
If you finde it good, let vs go by water.
Sir, that which liketh you pleaseth mee infinitely.
Where shall we then ship in?
Sir, at S. Paul his Key.
It is true, sir, a very commodious place.
Sir, enter then into the Boat.
That will I not doe by no meanes.
Sir, doth it please you to enter into the Boat?
Sir, to what end serue those ceremonies betweene you and I?
Sir, I will enter then for to obey you.
We are happy to haue two such strong men.
Euen as the Carters do serue vs by land, so also the mariners and watermen, doe vs pleasure and ease by water.
Truly sir, I am of your opinion.
How like you this going by water in Boats?
Sir, indeed I take pleasure to goe by water, but more to goe by land, and better without danger.
Why? is it by chance that those horses do please you that haue their bridles behind them?
Truely sir, they doe not please me at all, when I remember of a lesson that my father was wont to tell me now and then.
Sir, what lesson if it please you to tell mee?
Well sir, he tould me often, When I was able to goe by land, that I should neuer goe by water.
Notwithstanding, men were wont to say, That hee who trauelleth not by sea, knew not what the feare of God was.
And also he who trauells not by land, knows (no more) what solace, sport, and pleasure is.
Sir, shall wee passe vnder the bridge since that the tide goes forth?
Sir, to what vse are Bridges made?
To passe ouer them, and not vnder them.
Why will you then wee passe vnder them?
Ho, ho, sir, I vnderstand you well.
Where shall we take land?
Sir, at the end of the Bridge if it please you.
On this side, or yonder side of the Riuer?
Sir, as it shall be most commodious for you.
On this side then, for to bee the neerer the Exchange.
Sir, your opinion, What time of the tide is it?
Sir, I know not if it flowes or ebbes.
Me thinks it flows, if I be not deceived.
Sir, what haue you to doe at the Exchange, if it please you?
Sir, I am to dispatch some businesse of mine.
Sir, what businesse haue you there to bring to end?
Sir, I am to speake to a friend for some worke of mine.
Sir, thinke you to finde him there?
Yea forsooth, for he did promise me so yesterday.
On what side hath he assigned you to finde him?
Where the Italians do walke, or there about.
Think you that he wil keep his promise?
Yes sir, for I take him to bee an honest man.
Who promises and keepes not is not to bee trust to.
Sir, you are in the right, but I trust to his.
Good God keepe mee from those in whom I trust, for I shall keepe me from those whom I mistrust.
Sir, he gaue me so good words, that I could not refraine but trust him
Doe not you know, that the wicked deedes, and the faire words, doe beguile the wise men so well as fooles?
Sir, I know it well, but if he strike me with his sword, Ile strike him againe with my scabbert.
Sir, you will then render him a loafe for a cake.
Sir, if it be possible, do neuer ill to him that wishes you any, for by hatred Nature is corrupted.
Notwithstanding (Sir) the wicked ought to be punished.
It is true sir: but it is said, That to a Wolfes flesh, must be giuen a Dogs tooth.
Sir, what a clocke is it now?
Sir, it is about ten a clocke.
Sir, what houres be those that strike? know you?
Eleuen Sir, it is eleuen a clocke.
Sir, what a clocke may it be?
Sir, it cannot fail, but it must be twelue.
Sir, Ile goe see at the Sunne Dyall.
But (to the purpose) VVhere will you dine to day?
Truly (Sir) I know not yet where I shall dine.
Sir haue you made a promise any where?
Sir, in no wise, if I can remember.
Sir, doth it please you wee dine together?
Sir, I desire no other thing.
Shall we go then to some Ordinary?
Sir, as it shall please you.
Goe before and I will follow you.
Sir, if it please you, Ile goe before and guide you the way.
Sir, God doth favour me much, making me haue so honourable a Guide as you are.
Sir, I beleeue we are come too late.
Thinke not that, for it is yet very earely.
Sir, doth it please you to stay for me a little here, and Ile come presently againe.
Sir, in the mean time Ile walke a turn or two through the Exchange.
Sir. let it not displease you, Ile go speak with a Gentleman.
Sir, truly with all Authority, and not with licence.
Now goe to, I haue ended my busines: shall we goe home and dine?
Sir, I pray you, for I haue a good stomocke.
In good truth (Sir) that is a very good token of Health.
I giue God thankes, I finde my selfe alwaies able and frolike of the body.
Sir, and of your Purse, how do you feele it whiles?
Sir, alwaies ill disposed and languishing.
Truly Sir, the disease is so common that euery one feeles it.
Sir, haue not you drunke to day?
Not yet Sir, and you?
Sir, I goe neuer forth of my lodging before I drinke a good Cup.
I neuer vsed my selfe to it, but hence forth I will doe it.
My God Sir! see here Mr. Iohn comes to see you.
Truly it is he indeed, ah! Mr. Iohn , you are very heartily welcome.
Sir, I kisse your hands very humbly.
VVell my Masters, what shall wee doe vntill dinner time?
I agre to all things, provided wee doe any thing.
My maisters, Ile refer my selfe to the Company.
Let vs then make some game at the Tenis.
Iust, for this morning doth require it being so cold.
And there after we shall all go dine together.
And also after noone wee will goe see some Comedy.
How Sir, they are but repeating of old Histories.
Pardon me Sir, for in England are plaid true Comedies.
Yea Sir, and true Tragedies also, if men would seeke them.
My Masters, but let vs resolue to doe something SOURCE TEXT: sometehing for to SOURCE TEXT: ro flye from idlenesse.
Let us then goe play at the Tennis.
My Masters, then shall it bee needfull that one of vs stand by.
I will stand by, play ye two together.
Not so, if it please you wee will cast lots for it.
No Sir, make that I be a beholder, and not a player.
Goe to: since that you will doe so, let vs two play together.
Sir what advantage will you give me?
Sir, I will not play, if I play not like to like.
Sir, I am content for a set or two.
But to what Tennis court shall we go?
Sir, to that of the Charter-house.
Verily, that is the fairest of London.
But what shall Master Henrie doe in the meane time?
My Masters, Ile goe along with you and see you play.
Yea, forsooth Sir, you shall stay and behold vs, and bee judge, if wee play ill or well.
Mr. Henry , doth it please you to bee halfe in the play with me?
No Sir, I take no pleasure to see my money flie away like smoake.
Doe, doe Sir, bee halfe with him for my sake.
Sir, (if it please you) excuse mee I will not doe it.
Holo Boy, bring hither some Rackets, and some Bals.
Sirs, how many are ye in all?
Child, we be two that will play.
Sirs, will yee play a partie, or bandy?
We will play a Set, giue vs some good balls.
See here be two dozen, white & faire.
Master Henry , will you bee halfe with mee?
Pardon mee (Sir) neither will I bee halfe with you.
My Masters, let vs then obserue the law of play.
It is then your meaning to stake down money, is it not so?
Well, yea Sir, I see well that you vnderstand it.
Sir, here is mine, stake downe yours.
My Masters, whose turne is it to play?
It is I, because you are at the house.
Play then, and giue me a good ball.
Sir, doth it please you, that this be play?
As it shall please you, I doe not care.
Goe to, play Sir.
A losse: I haue fifteene.
Patience; play.
Say Boy, marke that chase.
Sir, behold it marked, and it is a great one.
Sir, you will lose it.
Demand it of the Standers by.
Fifteenes all.
I haue thirty, and a chase.
My Masters, is the Ball aboue or vnder the Roape?
Sir, me thinkes it is vnder more then a spanne.
I haue thirty for fifteene.
And I, I haue two chases.
Sir, the last is no chase, but a losse.
Sir, how is it a Losse?
Because you did strike it at the second bound.
You haue then forty; play.
And I a duce.
Sir, I haue an Advantage.
That was a braue stroake.
How is this my Masters? euerie one is against me.
I haue wonne the first game.
This is my mischance.
Mr. Henry , would you now be halfe in play with me?
Yea verily Sir, if I had done it at the beginning.
Truly (Sirs) I sweat, and I am all wet in water.
Let vs then quit the play, if it please you.
My Masters, who shall pay the balls?
It is I , how many dozen haue we had?
Ye haue had three dozen and a halfe.
See, here is money for thee, hold, pay thy selfe, and render me my rest.
What money is this here that I know it not?
Doest thou not see that it is a crown of the Sunne?
Sir, I haue no money for to change it to you, and then it is too light.
Weigh it then, for I know well that it is weight.
Truly Sir, it is too light by foure aces.
Sir, how much must you haue backe againe of your rest?
Fortie eight souce and a halfe.
Boy, Marker, render him his crowne, & Ile disburse for him.
Sir, doe me that curtesie for the like againe.
My Masters, since that we haue done, where shall we now goe?
As for me I will goe to my chamber.
Sir, what to doe there?
Truly Sir, it is for to take my rest, for I am weary.
My Masters, let vs rather go to my lodging.
Sir, that is the best advice, since it is not far from hence.
Let vs then goe apace, for it is late.
I see not yet the houre for to set me to the table.
Nor I also: but where haue you your Ordinary?
It is at my lodging with mine host and mine hostesse.
Are you there by Moneth, or by week with other table guests?
Yes Sir, we are there either by the moneth or by the weeke, as we will: and wee are vsed there like Princes, and very ioyfully.
Truly Sir, you doe very well, for a hundred thoughts shall neuer pay an ounce of debt.
Sir, haue you alwaies there good meat?
Truly, wee haue so much as sufficeth for the food of our bodies.
Sir, haue you where withall to break your fast in the morning?
Yes forsooth, sometimes (as to say) a little bread and butter.
Truly you are in good case if you haue no other thing.
You know well that he who is content is merry.
In truth Sir, Ile come and see you one of these mornings.
Sir. I pray you do it: do so much that I may see you now and then.
And you, do in such sort, that we may enjoy your presence.
Sir, doe not doubt; but I will come also and trouble you now and then.

sample.head: A MOST PLEASANT DISCOURSE OF AN EUILL LODGING, AN VGLY AND HARD-FAVOURED WIFE, AND A FAIRE AND HONOURABLE LADY IN BEAUTY: WITH A COUNTERFAIT COMPLEMENT OF A SLUGGISH LAZY BODY: BETWIXT IAMES AND HIS SERVANT LIPPA.
THE EIGHT CHAPTER.
sample.dialogue: This may be called a miracle that thou art come so quickly againe.
Sir, to say the truth, I haue taried no where.
What good newes hast thou heard? hast thou done my Busines?
Sir, I did see Master M. but not Master P. because he was gone abroad.
And what good newes hath Master M. told thee?
Sir, what would you he should say? you know well he is full of gentlenesse.
Child, I know it well, and so will I praise him all my Life time.
Verily Sir, he deserues that men honour him very much.
It is true: for he is so curious that hee growes fat doing good to others.
Truly Sir, if he eate no other thing he should be in a poore estate.
But what said he to thee?
Sir, hee rendreth you his Salutation with double vsury, and thankes you kindly for your good remembrance of him.
I am very glad that hee is in so good Health.
Moreover Sir, he sayes, If he could but set his foot abroad, hee would not faile to come himselfe and kisse your hands.
Goeth not hee then yet forth of his lodging?
Sir, with great paine can he stand on his Feet, he is so weake.
What did hee for to driue away the Time?
Sir, he was lying aboue his Bed, playing on the Lute.
Knowest thou if he playes well or no?
Sir, what know I? I know no more then a Swisser.
But how doth it seeme to thee?
Sir, according to my poore judgement me thinkes he playes very well.
He playes also very well on the Violl, on the Cister, Virginals, and on the Flute.
But what folks hath he in his lodging?
Sir, I haue seene no body there, but a deformed, hardfavoured, foule, heavy, deaf, blind, dumme, squint-eyed, blind of one eie, vncleane and hideous Baud.
Verily! child, his house may then bee called a Hell.
Sir, and yet worse, hauing such a wicked wife in his lodging.
Hath shee beene faire heretofore?

Sir, you may well thinke! for shee is cloathed like a Nunne, coiffed like a Puppet, lame of one Arme, crooked of one Foot, blinde of one Eie, the other bleare-ey'd, hulch-backt, crumpshouldered, bald, flat-nosed; and that little shee hath is all wrinckled, and with great hanging Eares.
Alas! I have great compassion on him: but what said she to thee?

Sir, all toothlesse as shee was, began to raile and scould on me, giving mee injuries, and disdaining mee on the Market place in the sight of everie one (I being ashamed to flee away) shee approched verie nigh mee and gave me a terrible blast of her stincking Breath.
It may be thou hast done some mischiefe unto her, in dispraise of her beautie, or by any bad or vndecent words.
Sir excuse mee, for I had never seene her before: and I beleeve there is not such an intricate and vilde Drabbe in the World.
O what terrible things thou makest me beleeve!
Then shee is much vnlike one that I have seene to day.
Sir, how know you if she be fairer then she that I have seene?
Because shee hath none of those Parts that thou esteemest her to haue.
Sir, which bee the fairest parts that a Woman ought to haue for to bee reputed, and to make her verily faire?
They be three White, three Black, three Red, three Long, three Short, three Big, three Fine, three Narrow, three Broad, and three Little.
Sir, make mee know that faire Worke of God (in his Creatures) if it please you. VERSE OMITTED.
Sir, thinke you that there are found such Women ouer all where?
Yea, a thousand in this Towne, and more.
Goe in the street and see if thou findest Maister R. walking there.
Sir, I did see him goe towards his lodging now presently.
Goe tell him that I would faine speake a word with him: and knocke at the Gate, to the end thou markest him well for to know him an other time, when I send thee thither.
Sir, I haue remarked him enough already: but if you will command mee thither any other thing, behold I am ready to dispatch your SOURCE TEXT: yvur Commandements.
Goe then quickly and pray him that hee would take the paines to come hither, if it please him.
